Privacy-Preserving Data Deduplication for Enhancing Federated Learning of Language Models

Aydin Abadi1 1Equal contribution. Listing order is alphabetical. Newcastle University
aydin.abadi@ncl.ac.uk â€ƒâ€ƒ Vishnu Asutosh Dasu1 Pennsylvania State University
vdasu@psu.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Sumanta Sarkar1 University of Warwick
sumanta.sarkar@warwick.ac.uk
Abstract

Deduplication is a vital preprocessing step that enhances machine learning model performance and saves training time and energy. However, enhancing federated learning through deduplication poses challenges, especially regarding scalability and potential privacy violations if deduplication involves sharing all clients' data. In this paper, we address the problem of deduplication in a federated setup by introducing a pioneering protocol, Efficient Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (EP-MPD). It efficiently removes duplicates from multiple clients' datasets without compromising data privacy. EP-MPD is constructed in a modular fashion, utilizing two novel variants of the Private Set Intersection protocol. Our extensive experiments demonstrate the significant benefits of deduplication in federated learning of large language models. For instance, we observe up to 19.61% improvement in perplexity and up to 27.95% reduction in running time. EP-MPD effectively balances privacy and performance in federated learning, making it a valuable solution for large-scale applications.

I Introduction

The application of machine learning (ML) has experienced rapid growth, becoming widely embraced by businesses due to its various benefits. As ML relies heavily on data, there is an inherent risk of privacy breaches associated with this process. Federated learning (FL) is one of the main steps towards privacy-preserving ML that allows training across multiple decentralized devices without exchanging data. In FL, devices compute local models based on their data and then share the local model updates with a central server. This server aggregates the updates to derive a global model that encapsulates the features of all the local data held by the individual devices [38].

The quality of the training data significantly influences the accuracy of an ML model. Data generated from real-world applications often lacks organization, leading to issues such as missing values, typos, format mismatches, outliers, or duplicated entries within the raw dataset. To ensure meaningful learning, the collected data must undergo a thorough data cleaning process [23]. Duplicated sequences are prevalent in text datasets. They can adversely affect the training process of Language Models (LMs). Lee et al. [31] investigated the Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus (C4) [44] dataset. They discovered a 61-word sequence within C4 that was repeated 61,036 times verbatim in the training dataset and 61 times in the validation set. As a result, the trained model generalized poorly on the dataset, and over 1%percent11\% of the unprompted model outputs were memorized and copied verbatim from the training dataset. Upon deduplicating the dataset, they reduced memorization by up to 10Ã—10\times and, in certain cases, even improved perplexity by up to 10%percent1010\%.

Additionally, memorization negatively affects the privacy and fairness of LMs [12]. Memorization makes language models vulnerable to membership inference attacks [48, 37], data extraction attacks [39, 13], and can lead to copyright violations as LMs can regurgitate training data sequences from copyrighted sources [28]. Carlini et al. [12] conclude that bigger LMs memorize more and more duplicates increase memorization. Kandpal et al. [27] show that the success of most privacy attacks on LMs is largely due to the duplication in the training datasets. Furthermore, in the FL setting, malicious clients can exploit the memorization of LMs to extract sensitive information from honest clients' datasets [46]. Therefore, we must adopt data-cleaning practices to improve model utility and reduce the risks of privacy attacks.

While deduplication can improve model performance and reduce memorization, it also enhances training efficiency in various aspects [31]. Removing duplicates reduces GPU time and minimizes training costs in terms of time, money, and carbon footprint. This streamlined process optimizes resource utilization and contributes to more sustainable ML practices [7, 47, 42]. Sustainable development is a global priority, and aligning ML practices with this theme is crucial.

Based on the discussions thus far, it is evident that the deduplication of training data offers numerous benefits. Several real-world applications involve training with FL such as healthcare [3], smart city [25], and edge computing [51]. Some of these applications pose a risk of duplicates in the local training data across multiple devices. For example, Google Keyboard suggestions from a user's text query rely on FL [22]. Local models are trained in situ on Android phones with user data. In this setting, many text queries typed by the users across multiple phones are the same.

Therefore, for a FL process to be efficient and effective, participating devices must perform deduplication. When a data owner solely intends to remove duplicates from their dataset, the privacy risk is minimal since the data is entirely under the owner's control. In the context of FL, the scenario shifts significantly when deduplication is introduced. Multiple devices participating in FL may possess overlapping data, even after deduplicating their datasets. If they aim to deduplicate the combined dataset, one approach could involve sharing their raw data with each other and checking for intersections. However, this approach compromises privacy.

Hence, there is a necessity for privacy-preserving deduplication in FL, where participating devices would collaboratively deduplicate the combined datasets in a privacy-preserving fashion. This paper demonstrates how deduplication can be executed in FL without compromising the privacy of the data belonging to the individual devices.

I-A Overview of Privacy-Preserving Deduplication in FL

Consider nodes D1,â€¦,Dnsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,D_{\scriptscriptstyle n} are involved in FL, where each Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has a dataset Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Effectively, the training in FL is conducted on the union of these datasets, i.e., â‹ƒi=1nSisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. If intersections exist among the datasets, FL will incorporate duplicates, leading to the drawbacks discussed earlier.

Consider nodes D1subscriptğ·1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and D2subscriptğ·2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}, each with datasets S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}, respectively implying that FL training occurs on S1âˆªS2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cup S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. If the intersection S1âˆ©S2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} is nonempty, training individually on S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} would mean training twice on the duplicate S1âˆ©S2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. Thus, one of D1subscriptğ·1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and D2subscriptğ·2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} should remove the duplicate S1âˆ©S2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. This should be done without harming each other's data privacy. Our solution applies private set intersection (PSI) which securely finds the intersection of S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} without revealing any other elements. Once D1subscriptğ·1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and D2subscriptğ·2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} learn S1âˆ©S2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} through PSI, D1subscriptğ·1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} will train on S1â€²=S1âˆ–S1âˆ©S2superscriptsubscriptğ‘†1â€²subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\setminus S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} and D2subscriptğ·2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} will train on S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. According to set theory, it holds that S1â€²âˆªS2=S1âˆªS2superscriptsubscriptğ‘†1â€²subscriptğ‘†2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}\cup S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cup S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. Hence, the resulting FL model remains as intended, while the training process is devoid of duplicates, avoiding the associated drawbacks. The scenario with two nodes seems straightforward. However, when more than two nodes participate, it becomes complicated. We now consider nğ‘›n nodes D1,â€¦,Dnsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,D_{\scriptscriptstyle n}, where each node Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has a set Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, âˆ€i,1â‰¤iâ‰¤nfor-allğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘›\forall i,1\leq i\leq n, and n>2ğ‘›2n>2.

Following the approach used in the two-node case, one might be tempted to (i) apply multi-party PSI to nğ‘›n nodes, (ii) find their intersection Insubscriptğ¼ğ‘›I_{\scriptscriptstyle n}, and (iii) let node D1subscriptğ·1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} train on S1â€²=S1âˆ–Insuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†1â€²subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ¼ğ‘›S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\setminus I_{\scriptscriptstyle n}, and rest of the nodes train on their own dataset Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. This method removes the duplicates that exist across all the nodes. However, this does not detect and remove the duplicates that exist among a subset of nodes. For instance, if there is a subset of kğ‘˜k nodes (k<nğ‘˜ğ‘›k<n) with a large intersection Iksubscriptğ¼ğ‘˜I_{\scriptscriptstyle k}, then Iksubscriptğ¼ğ‘˜I_{\scriptscriptstyle k} will remain in the full training dataset S1â€²â€‹â‹ƒ(â‹ƒi=2nSi)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}\bigcup(\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=2}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}) as duplicates. A generic multi-party PSI does not help in this case. Therefore, we need to consider each pair of nodes and remove the duplicates accordingly.

I-B Our Contributions

In this paper, our end goal is to develop a scheme such that allows multiple clients to benefit from deduplication while training on their data in a federated learning setup. The first requirement is an efficient deduplication of sets belonging to multiple clients. To address this, we introduce the notion of Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (P-MPD) in Section IV. This essentially describes a functionality that takes input datasets S1,â€¦,Smsubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘šS_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,S_{\scriptscriptstyle m} (potentially containing duplicates) from mğ‘šm clients and outputs the datasets S1â€²,â€¦,Smâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘†1â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘šâ€²S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime},\ldots,S_{\scriptscriptstyle m}^{\prime} such that â‹ƒi=1mSiâ€²=â‹ƒi=1mSisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime}=\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}S_{i}, where Siâ€²âˆ©Sjâ€²=âˆ…,iâ‰ jformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle j}^{\prime}=\emptyset,i\neq j. We realize that an efficient construction of P-MPD requires a substantially improved PSI protocol that supports scalability. This leads us to introduce a new notion for PSI which we call Group PSI (G-PSI) in Section III. The functionality of G-PSI takes sets from a group of clients and returns each client the intersection of their sets with all the other clients' sets. We provide constructions of Efficient Group PSI (EG-PSI) that efficiently realizes G-PSI, namely EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} in Figures 1 and 2, respectively. EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is based on symmetric key primitives such as pseudorandom permutation, while EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is developed using an oblivious pseudorandom function, which is a well-known public key primitive. With the building block EG-PSI, we build Efficient Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (EP-MPD) that realizes P-MPD as shown in Figure 4. We prove the security of EP-MPD, EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} within the simulation-based paradigm. Our construction of EP-MPD allows for efficient duplicate removal without compromising clients' data privacy, resulting in an improved model after running federated learning on the deduplicated datasets, as outlined in Figure 5.

We perform an extensive experimental evaluation to benchmark EP-MPD and the effect of the resulting deduplication on FL. The overall running time for EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, which employs EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} (symmetric key primitives based), is much less than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, which utilizes EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} (public key primitives based). Overall, clients enjoy relatively less computation time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. Our protocols can scale to large datasets and client counts. For example, when 50 clients have 219superscript2192^{\scriptscriptstyle 19} data points in their datasets comprising of 30%percent3030\% duplicates, then EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} takes 1160 seconds and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} takes 7653 seconds; client running time is 641 and 111 seconds in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} respectively. We experiment with 7 datasets, 2 language models, and 10 clients in FL. We achieve an improvement of up to 19.61% in perplexity and up to 27.95% improvement in GPU training time.

II-B Federated Learning (FL)

The concept of FL was proposed by McMahan et al. [38] as a framework for training an ML model where the training data are distributed across multiple devices. In FL, a server orchestrates the training of a global model by aggregating models locally computed by the clients on their local devices. Suppose there are nğ‘›n clients, and each client Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has a dataset Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. The server has the initial model ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}. It sends ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} to the clients, and each client performs gradient descent computation on their local dataset Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} as Jiâ€‹(Si,ğœ½)=1diâ€‹âˆ‘(x,y)âˆˆSiCâ€‹(ğœ½,(x,y)),subscriptğ½ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğœ½1subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptxğ‘¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ¶ğœ½xğ‘¦J_{i}({S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},\bm{\theta})=\frac{1}{d_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle(\textbf{x},y)\in{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}C(\bm{\theta},(\textbf{x},y)), where Cğ¶C is the cost function and di=|Si|subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–d_{\scriptscriptstyle i}=|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}|. The client Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} computes the local models as ğœ½iâ†ğœ½âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Jâ€‹(Si,ğœ½),â†subscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğœ½ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ½subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğœ½\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}\leftarrow\bm{\theta}-\eta\nabla J({S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},\bm{\theta}), where Î·ğœ‚\eta is the learning rate. After receiving the local models from the clients, the server performs an aggregated averaging on the local models to derive the global model as:

Î˜=1dâ€‹(d1â€‹ğœ½1+â€¦+dnâ€‹ğœ½n)Î˜1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğœ½1â€¦subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğœ½ğ‘›\Theta=\dfrac{1}{d}\big{(}d_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}+\ldots+d_{\scriptscriptstyle n}\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle n}\big{)} (1)

where d=âˆ‘i=1ndiğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d=\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}d_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is the total size of the dataset S=âˆ‘i=1nSiğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}=\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, and ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is the locally trained model on the dataset Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. This computation is repeated until the model converges.

While this framework achieves a basic level of privacy in which each user's data is not directly sent to the server, it is susceptible to advanced privacy attacks such as membership inference attacks [48, 37] and data extraction attacks [13, 46, 18, 4] as the client models Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{\scriptscriptstyle i} are aggregated in a non-private fashion on the server side. Some privacy-preserving FL protocols have attempted to mitigate these attacks by securely aggregating the client models. These protocols rely on cryptographic techniques like homomorphic encryption [14, 15], functional encryption [52], or secure aggregation [5, 9]. Additionally, differentially private training techniques [2] can be used to ensure differential privacy guarantees on the global model Î˜Î˜\Theta. We emphasize that in this paper, our proposed schemes are agnostic to the type of FL mechanism used.

II-C Causal Language Modeling (CLM)

Causal Language Modeling (CLM) is a natural language processing task where the goal of the language model is to predict the next word or token given a sequence of tokens. The language model autoregressively generates the next token until a pre-determined sequence length is reached or a special STOP token is generated. Given a sequence of nğ‘›n tokens ğ˜={y1,y2â€‹â€¦,ynâˆ’1,yn}ğ˜subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›\mathbf{Y}=\{y_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},y_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}\ldots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle n-1},y_{\scriptscriptstyle n}\}, the language model Î˜Î˜\Theta is trained to learn the following probability distribution:

The CLM training objective is to minimize the negative log-likelihood loss given by:

After training is complete, the text is autoregressively sampled from the language model i.e., y^t<nâˆ¼Î˜â€‹(yt|y1,â€¦,ytâˆ’1)similar-tosubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘›Î˜conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡1\hat{y}_{\scriptscriptstyle t<n}\sim\Theta(y_{\scriptscriptstyle t}|y_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle t-1}).

The perplexity metric is commonly used to evaluate the performance of the language model to determine how well it has learned the probability distribution in EquationÂ 2. The perplexity Pâ€‹Pğ‘ƒğ‘ƒPP of a sequence ğ²ğ²\mathbf{y} is defined as:

A lower perplexity score implies that model Î˜Î˜\Theta has been trained well to estimate the real-world probability distribution. Informally, a sequence with a low perplexity score implies that the model is less ``surprised'' by a sequence of tokens.

II-D Security Model

In this paper, we use the simulation-based paradigm of secure multi-party computation [21] to define and prove the proposed protocol. Since we focus on the static passive (semi-honest) adversarial model, we will restate the security definition within this context.

II-D1 Two-party Computation

A two-party protocol Î“Î“\Gamma is captured by specifying a random process that maps a pair of input to a pair of outputs (one output for each party). Such process is referred to as a functionality denoted by f:{0,1}âˆ—Ã—{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ—Ã—{0,1}âˆ—:ğ‘“â†’superscript01superscript01superscript01superscript01f:\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}, where f:=(f1,f2)assignğ‘“subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2f:=(f_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},f_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}). For every input pair (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y), the output pair is a random variable (f1â€‹(x,y),f2â€‹(x,y))subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(f_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}(x,y),f_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(x,y)), such that the party with input xğ‘¥x wishes to obtain f1â€‹(x,y)subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥ğ‘¦f_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}(x,y) while the party with input yğ‘¦y wishes to receive f2â€‹(x,y)subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘¥ğ‘¦f_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(x,y). The above functionality can be easily extended to more than two parties.

II-D2 Security in the Presence of Passive Adversaries

In the passive adversarial model, the party corrupted by such an adversary correctly follows the protocol specification. Nonetheless, the adversary obtains the internal state of the corrupted party, including the transcript of all the messages received, and tries to use this to learn information that should remain private. Loosely speaking, a protocol is secure if whatever can be computed by a corrupt party in the protocol can be computed using its input and output only.

In the simulation-based model, it is required that a partyâ€™s view in a protocol's execution can be simulated given only its input and output. This implies that the parties learn nothing from the protocol's execution. Formally, in two-party case, party iğ‘–iâ€™s view (during the execution of Î“Î“\Gamma) on input pair (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) is denoted by ğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—iÎ“â€‹(x,y)superscriptsubscriptğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—ğ‘–Î“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\scriptscriptstyle\Gamma}(x,y) and equals (w,ri,m1i,â€¦,mti)ğ‘¤superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘–â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–(w,r^{\scriptscriptstyle i},m_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\scriptscriptstyle i},...,m_{\scriptscriptstyle t}^{\scriptscriptstyle i}), where wâˆˆ{x,y}ğ‘¤ğ‘¥ğ‘¦w\in\{x,y\} is the input of itâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{\scriptscriptstyle th} party, risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is the outcome of this party's internal random coin tosses, and mjisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘—ğ‘–m_{\scriptscriptstyle j}^{\scriptscriptstyle i} represents the jtâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡â„j^{\scriptscriptstyle th} message this party receives. The output of the itâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{\scriptscriptstyle th} party during the execution of Î“Î“\Gamma on (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) is denoted by ğ–®ğ—ğ—ğ—‰ğ—ğ—iÎ“â€‹(x,y)superscriptsubscriptğ–®ğ—ğ—ğ—‰ğ—ğ—ğ‘–Î“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mathsf{Output}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\scriptscriptstyle\Gamma}(x,y) and can be generated from its own view of the execution.

II-E Pseudorandom Function and Permutation

Informally, a pseudorandom function ğ™¿ğšğ™µ(.)\mathtt{PRF}(.) is a deterministic function that takes a key of length Î»ğœ†\lambda and an input of length uğ‘¢u; and outputs a value of length vğ‘£v indistinguishable from an output of a truly random function. More formally, a pseudorandom function can be defined as ğ™¿ğšğ™µ:{0,1}Î»Ã—{0,1}uâ†’{0,1}v:ğ™¿ğšğ™µâ†’superscript01ğœ†superscript01ğ‘¢superscript01ğ‘£\mathtt{PRF}:\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle\lambda}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle v}, where Î»ğœ†\lambda is the security parameter.

The definition of a pseudorandom permutation, ğ™¿ğšğ™¿:{0,1}Î»Ã—{0,1}uâ†’{0,1}u:ğ™¿ğšğ™¿â†’superscript01ğœ†superscript01ğ‘¢superscript01ğ‘¢\mathtt{PRP}:\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle\lambda}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}, is very similar to that of a pseudorandom function, with a difference; namely, it is required the keyed function ğ™¿ğšğ™¿â€‹(k,â‹…)ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ‘˜â‹…\mathtt{PRP}(k,\cdot) to be indistinguishable from a uniform permutation, instead of a uniform function. In cryptographic schemes that involve ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ™¿ğšğ™¿\mathtt{PRP}, sometimes honest parties may be required to compute the inverse of pseudorandom permutation, i.e., ğ™¿ğšğ™¿âˆ’1â€‹(k,â‹…)superscriptğ™¿ğšğ™¿1ğ‘˜â‹…\mathtt{PRP}^{\scriptscriptstyle-1}(k,\cdot), as well. In this case, it would require that ğ™¿ğšğ™¿â€‹(k,â‹…)ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ‘˜â‹…\mathtt{PRP}(k,\cdot) be indistinguishable from a uniform permutation even if the distinguisher is additionally given oracle access to the inverse of the permutation.

II-F Oblivious Pseudorandom Function

An Oblivious Pseudorandom Function (OPRF) is a protocol that involves a client and a server. OPRF enables the client with input xâˆˆ{0,1}uğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘¢x\in\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}, and the server with key kâˆˆ{0,1}Î»ğ‘˜superscript01ğœ†k\in\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle\lambda} to execute an instance of ğ™¿ğšğ™µğ™¿ğšğ™µ\mathtt{PRF}. Informally, the security of an OPRF asserts that, by the completion of OPRF, the client only learns the output of ğ™¿ğšğ™µğ™¿ğšğ™µ\mathtt{PRF}Â is evaluated on inputs kğ‘˜k and xğ‘¥x, i.e., ğ™¿ğšğ™µâ€‹(k,x)ğ™¿ğšğ™µğ‘˜ğ‘¥\mathtt{PRF}(k,x) while the server gains no information, e.g., about the input of the client and the output of ğ™¿ğšğ™µğ™¿ğšğ™µ\mathtt{PRF}.

II-G Trusted Execution Environments

Trusted Execution Environment (ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}), also known as a secure enclave, constitutes a secure processing environment comprising processing, memory, and storage hardware units [41, 54]. Within this environment, the code and data residing in them remain isolated from other layers in the software stack, including the operating system. An ideal ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} guarantees the preservation of data integrity and confidentiality. Moreover, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} can provide remote attestation capabilities, allowing a party to remotely verify the execution of an enclave on a genuine ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} hardware platform. Given the assumption that the physical CPU remains uncompromised, enclaves are shielded from attackers with physical access to the machine, including the memory and system bus.

Side-channel attacks on different deployments of ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}s have been demonstrated in the literature [49]. These attacks pose a threat as they could enable attackers to extract secrets from ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}s. Nevertheless, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}s technologies have been evolving to address and mitigate side-channel attacks.

Our security, trust, and system assumptions regarding ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}s are conservative. Specifically, as detailed in Sections IV-B1 and III-B, our solution (i) avoids disclosing any plaintext messages or private keys to ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} and (ii) does not expect ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} to maintain an extensive storage and memory space or possess strong processing resources. Instead, we establish a formal model and construction under the assumption that ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} guarantees execution integrity (and authenticity), and ensures minimal confidentiality. Specifically, we formally demonstrate that ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} at the most only learns the size of the encrypted computation result (i.e., the intersections' cardinality). In our work, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} can be seamlessly substituted with any semi-honest server that does not collude with other entities.

III Group PSI (G-PSI)

III-A Formal Definition of G-PSI

In this section, we present the concept of Group PSI (G-PSI). In G-PSI, there are two groups of clients, ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}, where each group contains mğ‘šm clients, ğ’¢j:{ğ’j,1,â€¦,ğ’j,m}:subscriptğ’¢ğ‘—subscriptğ’ğ‘—1â€¦subscriptğ’ğ‘—ğ‘š\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle j}:\{\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,m}\}, 0â‰¤jâ‰¤10ğ‘—10\leq j\leq 1. Each client ğ’j,1subscriptğ’ğ‘—1\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,1} has a set Sj,1subscriptğ‘†ğ‘—1{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,1}, such that no pair of clients' sets in the same group share a common element.

Informally, G-PSI allows every client in one group to (efficiently) find the intersection that their set has with the set of every client of the other group, without allowing them to learn anything beyond that about other clients' set elements. To achieve a high level of computational efficiency in G-PSI, we will involve a third-party ğ’¯â€‹ğ’«ğ’¯ğ’«\mathcal{TP} that assists the clients with computing the intersection. The functionality fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSI{f}_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} that G-PSI computes takes a set Sj,isubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} from every client ğ’j,isubscriptğ’ğ‘—ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} and no input from ğ’¯â€‹ğ’«ğ’¯ğ’«\mathcal{TP}. It returns (i) to every client ğ’j,isubscriptğ’ğ‘—ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} a vector vâ†’j,isubscriptâ†’ğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘–\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} which contains the intersection that ğ’j,isubscriptğ’ğ‘—ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}'s set has with every other client's set in the other group and (ii) to ğ’¯â€‹ğ’«ğ’¯ğ’«\mathcal{TP} an empty set âˆ…\emptyset. Hence, functionality fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} can be formally defined as follows.

Since ğ’¯â€‹ğ’«ğ’¯ğ’«\mathcal{TP} performs computation on all clients' encrypted sets, there is a possibility of leakage to ğ’¯â€‹ğ’«ğ’¯ğ’«\mathcal{TP}. Depending on the protocol that realizes fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} this leakage could contain different types of information; for instance, it could contain (i) the size of the intersection of any two clients' sets, or (ii) the size of the intersection of all clients' sets, or (iii) nothing at all. Often such leakage is defined by a leakage function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} that takes all parties (encoded) inputs and returns the amount of leakage.

We assert that a protocol securely realizes fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} if (1) it reveals nothing beyond a predefined leakage to ğ’¯â€‹ğ’«ğ’¯ğ’«\mathcal{TP} and (2) whatever can be computed by a client in the protocol can be obtained from its input and output. This is formalized under the simulation paradigm. We require a clientâ€™s view during an execution of G-PSI to be simulatable given its input and output. We require that the view of ğ’¯â€‹ğ’«ğ’¯ğ’«\mathcal{TP} can be simulated given the leakage.

III-B Efficient Construction of G-PSI

In this section, we introduce two efficient protocols that realize G-PSI. The first one, called EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, is highly efficient and based on symmetric key cryptography. The second one, called EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, is based on OPRF (in turn depends on public key cryptography) and discloses less information to ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} than the former does. Thus, these two protocols trade-off between performance and leakage amount.

III-B1 EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}

At a high level, EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} operates as follows. Initially, each client in group ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} agrees with every client in group ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} on a secret key. Every client encrypts its set elements using every key it has agreed on with other clients (in a different group).

Each client, for every encrypted set element, temporally stores a triple that includes (i) the encrypted element, (ii) the key used to encrypt that element, and (iii) the index of the client with whom the key was shared. These triples will enable the client to efficiently (a) retrieve the correct key and (b) identify the client with whom it has the element in common when presented with an encrypted element. Once all elements are encrypted using the corresponding keys, each client transmits only its encrypted elements to ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}.

Given the sets of encrypted elements from all clients, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} aggregates these sets and identifies the encrypted elements that appear more than once. Subsequently, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} forwards to a client those encrypted elements that (1) appear more than once and (2) are among the messages that the client initially sent to ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}. Upon receiving each encrypted element from ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}, a client searches its local list of triples to locate the corresponding key and the index lğ‘™l representing a specific client. Utilizing the key, the client decrypts the element and regards the resultant element as one of the elements within the intersection it shares with the lğ‘™l-th client. For a comprehensive description of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, refer to Figure 1.

The only information that ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} learns in EG-PSI is the size of the intersection of any two clients' sets, called pair-wise intersection cardinality. Below, we formally define it.

Definition 3 (pair-wise intersection cardinality).

Let (S0,1â€²,â€¦,S0,mâ€²âŸğ’¢0),subscriptâŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²01â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²0ğ‘šsubscriptğ’¢0(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}}), (S1,1â€²,â€¦,S1,mâ€²âŸğ’¢1)subscriptâŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²11â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1ğ‘šsubscriptğ’¢1(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}) be two groups ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} of (encrypted) sets. Then, vector sâ†’â†’ğ‘ \vec{s} represents the pair-wise intersection cardinality: sâ†’=[sâ†’0,1,â€¦,\vec{s}=[\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots, sâ†’0,m,sâ†’1,1,â€¦,sâ†’1,m]\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}], where sâ†’j,i=[|[Sj,iâˆ©S1âˆ’j,1]|,â€¦,|[Sj,iâˆ©S1âˆ’j,m]|]subscriptâ†’ğ‘ ğ‘—ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘†ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†1ğ‘—1â€¦delimited-[]subscriptğ‘†ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†1ğ‘—ğ‘š\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}=\Big{[}\big{|}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,1}]\big{|},\ldots,\big{|}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,m}]\big{|}\Big{]}, 0â‰¤jâ‰¤10ğ‘—10\leq j\leq 1, and 1â‰¤iâ‰¤m1ğ‘–ğ‘š1\leq i\leq m.

Definition 4.

Let sâ†’â†’ğ‘ \vec{s} be a pair-wise intersection cardinality of two groups ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} of encrypted sets: (S0,1â€²,â€¦,S0,mâ€²âŸğ’¢0),(S1,1â€²,â€¦,S1,mâ€²âŸğ’¢1)subscriptâŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²01â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²0ğ‘šsubscriptğ’¢0subscriptâŸsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²11â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1ğ‘šsubscriptğ’¢1(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}}),(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}), with respect to Definition 3. Then, leakage function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} is defined as follows: â„’â€‹((S0,1â€²,â€¦,S0,mâ€²),(S1,1â€²,â€¦,S1,mâ€²))â†’sâ†’â†’â„’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²01â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²0ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²11â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1ğ‘šâ†’ğ‘ \mathcal{L}\Big{(}({S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}),({S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m})\Big{)}\rightarrow\vec{s}.

Theorem 1.

Let fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} be the functionality defined in Relation 5. Also, let â„’â„’\mathcal{L} be the leakage function presented in Definition 4. If ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ™¿ğšğ™¿\mathtt{PRP} is a secure pseudorandom permutation, then EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} (presented in Figure 1) securely realizes fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}}, with respect to Definition 2.

We refer to Appendix -A for the proof of Theorem 1.

III-B2 EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}

In this section, we present EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} which is the second variant of EG-PSI. Note that ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} in EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is able to learn the cardinality of the intersection of each pair of clients' sets. We aim to reduce this leakage in EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. However, EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is no longer based on symmetric key cryptography as it depends on OPRF. To the best of our knowledge, all the constructions of OPRFs are based on public key cryptography whose security depends on some hard problem assumptions. The same holds for EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

A brief overview of the construction of EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is as follows. We have two groups of clients ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} having their own set that they want to find the pairwise intersection. There is a ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} that has a key kğ‘˜k for a ğ™¿ğšğ™µğ™¿ğšğ™µ\mathtt{PRF}. During the setup, each client interacts with ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} to encrypt their set using ğ™¿ğšğ™µâ€‹(k,â‹…)ğ™¿ğšğ™µğ‘˜â‹…\mathtt{PRF}(k,\cdot) through an OPRF call. Then, each client of group ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} will send their encrypted set to every client of ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}. Upon receiving an encrypted set from a client of ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}, each client of ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} determines the intersection with their encrypted set. Once the client finds the intersection, it marks the index of the elements in the intersection and consider the elements with the same index in the unencrypted set as elements in the intersection. Similarly, each client of ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} shares their encrypted set with each client of ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and follows the same steps. Ultimately, every client of ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} knows the intersection between their set and all the sets belonging to the clients of ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}, and the other way around. We give a detailed description of EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} in Figure 2.

In EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} does not participate in the protocol except the OPRF evaluation and that is also a one-time activity. As a result, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} does not learn anything about the set intersection, it only learns the cardinality of each client's set.

Theorem 2.

Let fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} be the functionality defined in Relation 5 (on page 5). Also, let â„’â„’\mathcal{L} be the leakage function presented in Definition 4 with the empty output. If OPRF is secure, then EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} securely realizes fG-PSIsubscriptğ‘“G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}}, w.r.t. Definition 2.

Appendix -B outlines the proof of Theorem 2. Note that both variants remain secure in the presence of semi-honest adversaries. However, if ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} or a client is a malicious (or active) adversary, then it can affect the correctness of the result, without being detected.

IV Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (P-MPD)

IV-A Formal Definition of P-MPD

P-MPD considers the setting where there are nğ‘›n clients C={ğ’1,â€¦,ğ’m}ğ¶subscriptğ’1â€¦subscriptğ’ğ‘šC=\{\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\} and each ğ’iâˆˆCsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ¶\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}\in C has a set Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. P-MPD enables the clients to (efficiently) remove duplicates from their local sets such that after the deduplication the concatenation of all clients' local sets equals the union of their initial sets.

The functionality fP-MPDsubscriptğ‘“P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} that P-MPD computes takes a set Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} from each ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. It returns an updated (i.e., deduplicated) set Siâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘–S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} to each ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Formerly, fP-MPDsubscriptğ‘“P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} can be defined as follows:

fP-MPDâ€‹(S1,â€¦,Sm)â†’(S1â€²,â€¦,Smâ€²),â†’subscriptğ‘“P-MPDsubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘šf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}}(S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,S_{\scriptscriptstyle m})\rightarrow(S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}), (8)

where âˆ‘i=1mSiâ€²=â‹ƒi=1mSi=Sâˆªsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘–1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†\sum\limits^{\scriptscriptstyle m}_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}=\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle\cup} and Sâˆªsubscriptğ‘†S_{\cup} denotes the union of all initial sets and contains only unique elements.

To maintain generality, we define a leakage function, denoted as ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}. The output of this function relies on the protocol implementing fP-MPDsubscriptğ‘“P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}}. We assert that a protocol securely realizes fP-MPDsubscriptğ‘“P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} if whatever can be computed by a party in the protocol can be derived solely from its individual input and output, given the output of ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}. Below, we formally state it.

IV-B Constructions of P-MPD

IV-B1 Construction Based on EG-PSI

We introduce a pioneering protocol called Efficient Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (EP-MPD) that realizes P-MPD efficiently. The idea behind EP-MPD's design involves constructing a binary tree with leaf nodes representing the clientsâ€™ indices. At each level, each cluster is formed with two different groups of clients, namely ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Subsequently, EG-PSI is recursively applied to the sets of clients sharing the same cluster until the tree's root is reached. After each invocation of EG-PSI, the clients of ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} update their sets by removing the intersections, returned by EG-PSI, from their local sets. These updated sets are then used as input in the subsequent EG-PSI invocation.

Next, we delve into further detail. We begin by sorting the clients' indices in ascending order. Next, we construct a binary tree such that the leaf nodes represent the clients' indices.

At level d=1ğ‘‘1d=1, commencing from the left-hand side, every two clients form a cluster. Within each cluster, the first client is assigned to group ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and the second client to group ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Then, the clients within the same cluster engage in an instance of EG-PSI. Upon the return of the sets' intersection by EG-PSI, only the client situated on the left-hand side, specifically the one with the smaller index, modifies its local set by eliminating the elements of the intersection from its sets. This process is outlined in Figure 3(a).

At level d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, starting from the left-hand side, every set of 2dsuperscript2ğ‘‘2^{\scriptscriptstyle d} clients form a cluster. Within each cluster, the initial 2d2=2superscript2ğ‘‘22\frac{2^{\scriptscriptstyle d}}{2}=2 clients enter group ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and the remainder (i.e., the remaining 222 clients) enter group ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Subsequently, the clients within the same cluster engage in an instance of EG-PSI. Once again, upon the return of their sets' intersection by EG-PSI, the clients possessing the smaller indices update their local sets. This procedure is illustrated in Figure 3(b).

The process continues until level d=log2â¡mğ‘‘subscript2ğ‘šd=\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}{m} is reached. At this point, all mğ‘šm clients collectively engage in an instance of EG-PSI. Each 2d2=m2superscript2ğ‘‘2ğ‘š2\frac{2^{\scriptscriptstyle d}}{2}=\frac{m}{2} clients enter group ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and the remaining m2ğ‘š2\frac{m}{2} clients enter group ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. These mğ‘šm clients jointly participate in an instance of EG-PSI. Similarly to previous steps, the clients with the smaller indices update their local sets based on the output of EG-PSI. This procedure is outlined in Figure 3(c).

Figure 4 presents a detailed description of EP-MPD. For the sake of simplicity, we assume that mğ‘šm is a power of 2 in EP-MPD's description. However, we do not impose on the number of clients. Non-powers of 2 will result in incomplete sub-trees in the formation of clusters in the DE protocol where each group may have an unequal number of clients. This does not affect the EP-MPD protocol execution.

IV-C Naive Approaches

IV-C1 Running a Two-Party PSI Multiple Times

One might be tempted to allow each client to invoke an existing two-party PSI with every other client. However, this approach in total requires (m2)=Oâ€‹(m2)binomialğ‘š2ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘š2{m\choose 2}=O(m^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}) invocations of the two-party PSI. Whereas EP-MPD requires only âˆ‘i=1log2â¡(m)(m2i)=mâˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptsubscript2ğ‘šğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscript2ğ‘–ğ‘š1\sum\limits^{\scriptscriptstyle\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)}_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}(\frac{m}{2^{\scriptscriptstyle i}})=m-1 invocations of our efficient tailor-made PSI, EG-PSI. To provide concrete values, when m=256ğ‘š256m=256, the naive scheme requires 32,640 invocations of a standard two-party PSI, whereas our scheme requires only 255255255 invocations of EG-PSI.

IV-C2 Running Multi-Party PSI Once

One might be tempted to execute an existing multi-party PSI protocol only once on all clients' sets, hoping to identify and subsequently remove duplicated elements. Nevertheless, this approach falls short of identifying all duplications. The limitation arises from the fact that a multi-party PSI can uncover elements common to all clients, making it incapable of detecting elements shared among only a subset of clients.

IV-C3 Deduplicating all Sets at Once

There is a simplified version of EP-MPD. In this variant, each client reaches an agreement with the others on a secret key. Subsequently, each client encrypts its set elements using every key agreed upon with the other clients. Finally, all clients transmit their encrypted set elements to ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}. Upon receiving the encrypted sets from all clients, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} identifies all duplicated elements. It then transmits to each client: (1) the duplicated elements found in the original elements that the respective client sent to ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}, and (2) the index of the client with which it shares the same element. Based on ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}'s response, the clients with smaller indices update their local sets accordingly.

However, this approach requires that ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} maintains a local storage or memory space equal to the size of the concatenation of all encrypted sets. In contrast, EP-MPD with the underlying EG-PSI building block, allows ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} to have a substantially smaller storage or memory space. This is achieved because, before ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} receives all clients' encrypted sets at level d=lâ€‹oâ€‹g2â€‹(m)ğ‘‘ğ‘™ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘”2ğ‘šd=log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m), clients apply updates to their sets multiple times. This iterative process progressively reduces the size of the clients' sets, and the reduction can be particularly significant when the number of duplications is substantial.

IV-D Security Analysis

In any secure (multi-party) deduplication protocol, a participating client will learn the exact redundant elements within its set upon the protocol's completion. However, in EP-MPD, a client gains slightly more information. To be specific, upon the completion of EP-MPD, each client acquires the knowledge of the index (or identity) of the client that shares the redundant element. This additional information gained by a client during the execution of EP-MPD is formally defined as the output of a leakage function ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} which we define below.

ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} takes as input (i) sets S1,â€¦,Smsubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘š{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}, where each set Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} belongs to client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, and (ii) sets R1,â€¦,Rmsubscriptğ‘…1â€¦subscriptğ‘…ğ‘šR_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,R_{\scriptscriptstyle m}, where each Risubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} contains the redundancy (or intersection) that a set Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has with every other set. ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} outputs to the iğ‘–i-th client a set Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{\scriptscriptstyle i} of triples, where each triple is of the form (ri,l,i,l)subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘™(r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l},i,l), ri,lâˆˆRisubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘™subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l}\in R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is a redundancy between sets Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} and Slsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘™{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle l}.

Definition 6.

Let S={S1,â€¦,Sm}ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘šS=\{{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\} be a set of sets, where each set Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} belongs to client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Also, let R={R1,â€¦,Rm}ğ‘…subscriptğ‘…1â€¦subscriptğ‘…ğ‘šR=\{R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,R_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\} be a set of sets, where each set Risubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} comprises the redundancy that Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has with every other jğ‘—j-th set, for all jğ‘—j, 1â‰¤jâ‰¤m1ğ‘—ğ‘š1\leq j\leq m and iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j. Then, leakage function ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} is defined as follows: ğ’²â€‹(S,R)â†’(Q1,â€¦,Qm)â†’ğ’²ğ‘†ğ‘…subscriptğ‘„1â€¦subscriptğ‘„ğ‘š\mathcal{W}(S,R)\rightarrow(Q_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,Q_{\scriptscriptstyle m}), where each Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is a set of triples of the form (ri,l,i,l)subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘™(r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l},i,l), ri,lâˆˆRisubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘™subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l}\in R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is a redundancy between sets Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} and Slsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘™{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle l}.

Theorem 3.

Let fP-MPDsubscriptğ‘“P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} be the functionality defined in Relation 8 and ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} be the leakage function presented in Definition 6. If EG-PSI is secure (w.r.t. Definition 2), then EP-MPD (presented in Figure 4) securely realizes fP-MPDsubscriptğ‘“P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}}, w.r.t. Definition 5.

The proof of Theorem 3 can be found in Appendix -C.

V Enhanced FL: Applying EP-MPD to FL

With all essential building blocks in place, we are prepared to elucidate the complete functionality of the system. There are clients ğ’1,â€¦,ğ’msubscriptğ’1â€¦subscriptğ’ğ‘š\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle m} having the sets S1,â€¦,Smsubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘š{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}, where each Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} belongs to client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} respectively. Phase 1 involves each client conducting local deduplication. Since the local deduplication is a private computation there is no privacy requirement. The data owners can apply deduplication techniques as illustrated in [31] which results in having a set Siâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–â€²{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime} free of duplicates by each client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Subsequently, in Phase 2 they employ EP-MPD to eliminate duplicates across all clients. At the end of this phase, client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} gets an updated set Siâ€²â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–â€²â€²{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime\prime}, such that âˆ‘i=1mSiâ€²â€²=â‹ƒi=1mSiâ€².superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–â€²â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–â€²\sum\limits_{i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime\prime}=\bigcup\limits_{i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime}. Moving to Phase 3, they adopt a FL protocol (outlined in Section II-B) to train the model. Further details of this procedure are provided in FigureÂ 5.

VI Experiments

VI-A Implementation Details

We implement the EP-MPD protocol in python=3.10. We use AES with a 128-bit key in CBC mode from the cryptography library as a PRP in EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. To realize an OPRF in EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, we use the OPRF algorithm proposed in [11] from the oprf library. All EP-MPD experiments are conducted on a batch computing facility with a Dual Intel Xeon E5-2660 v3 @ 2.6 GHz CPU and 60 GB RAM.

For the FL experiments, we implement a FL setting for CLMs using python=3.10 with the transformers=4.40.1 and torch=2.3 libraries. We implement the FedAvg [38] algorithm for FL training to analyze the effect of EP-MPD on FL's performance. However, in practice, we recommend combining EP-MPD with privacy-preserving FL protocols for end-to-end privacy guarantees. All FL experiments are conducted on a server with an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6336Y CPU @ 2.40GHz CPU and NVIDIA RTX A6000 GPU.

We run all clients sequentially on a machine for both experiments. However, to emulate a real-world setting where clients run on different devices at the same time, we first compute the individual client running times and then estimate the real-world distributed running time by assuming the clients have run simultaneously. We open-source our implementations111https://github.com/vdasu/deduplication.

While implementing EP-MPD, we have two options for the EG-PSI module: EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. We observe that EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}-based EP-MPD calls an OPRF function for every client in the leaf nodes of the EP-MPD tree, returning an encryption of the clients' sets. As clients move to upper levels, their set elements remain unchanged, with only the cardinality potentially changing. Therefore, except at the bottom level, OPRF calls are unnecessary for encryption, allowing the same encrypted set or their subsets to be reused at other levels. Thus, we have slightly adjusted the implementation. This significantly reduces time without compromising security properties, as reflected in our experiments.

VI-B EP-MPD Benchmarks

VI-B1 Experimental Setup

We designed three experiment settings to benchmark the performance of EP-MPD. The three settings analyze the effect of the number of clients, dataset size, and duplication percentage on the runtime of EP-MPD. All experiments were performed with both EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} as building blocks. The duplication percentage refers to the percentage of samples in a client's dataset present in another client's dataset. The three experiment settings are:

  1. a.

    The dataset size is fixed at |Si|=219subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–superscript219|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}|=2^{\scriptscriptstyle 19}, the duplication percentage at 30%percent3030\%, while the number of clients mğ‘šm is varied. Specifically, mğ‘šm is set to each value in {10,20,30,40,50}1020304050\{10,20,30,40,50\}.

  2. b.

    The number of clients is fixed at 505050 and the duplication percentage at 30%percent3030\%, while the dataset size |Si|subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}| is varied. Specifically, |Si|subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}| is set to each value in {210,211,213,215,217,219}superscript210superscript211superscript213superscript215superscript217superscript219\{2^{\scriptscriptstyle 10},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 11},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 13},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 15},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 17},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 19}\}.

  3. c.

    The database size |Si|subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}| is fixed at 219superscript2192^{\scriptscriptstyle 19}, the number of clients at 505050, while the duplication percentage is varied. Specifically, it is set to each value in {10%,30%,50%,70%,90%}percent10percent30percent50percent70percent90\{10\%,30\%,50\%,70\%,90\%\}.

We create pairwise duplicates between clients such that every client has a unique duplicate element with every other client. All set elements are 32-bit integers. We assume that the ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} can receive data in parallel from the clients. All other interactions that require computation between ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} and clients occur sequentially. In the remainder of this section, by EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} we mean the EP-MPD that uses EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} respectively.

VI-B2 Effect of Client Count

FigureÂ 6 depicts the effect of the number of clients on (a) EP-MPD running time, (b) the average running time of clients, and (c) ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} running time. FigureÂ 6(a) demonstrates that the EP-MPD running time increases linearly with the number of clients for both EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. The increase in the client count rises the number of PRP and OPRF evaluations as the total number of elements across all clients grows. We observe that EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is about 7â€“10Ã—7\mbox{--}10\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

The average running time of the client however shows a different trend. The client running time in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} increases linearly with the client count and is always greater than â€“ up to 6Ã—6\times â€“ the running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. The running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant as the number of clients increases. In EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, the client-side running time increases with the number of clients, because each client has to perform more PRP evaluations. However, in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, the number of OPRF evaluations is equal to the number of elements in each client's set. Additionally, in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, the clients perform the PRP evaluations at every level of the tree. However, in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} the OPRF evaluations are only performed once when the clients are at the leaf level.

The running time of ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} follows a similar trend to the EP-MPD running time. The ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is always higher than EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. Both exhibit linear increases in running time as the number of clients increases. The running time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is much higher as the OPRF evaluations are relatively expensive.

VI-B3 Effect of Dataset Size

FigureÂ 7 illustrates the effect of dataset size on EP-MPD running time, the average running time of clients, and ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} running time. From FigureÂ 7(a), it is evident that the EP-MPD running time grows linearly with increasing the dataset size. EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 8Ã—8\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. As the dataset size increases, the number of PRP and OPRF evaluations grows, thereby increasing the EP-MPD running time.

FigureÂ 7(b) shows the effect of dataset size on client running time. Unlike increasing the client count, increasing the dataset size increases the client running time of both EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. We observe this difference because an increase in dataset size increases the number of OPRF evaluations while any change in the client count does not. The client running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is up to 7Ã—7\times faster than EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}.

FigureÂ 7(c) depicts the effect of dataset size on the running time of ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}. The growth of dataset size increases the OPRF evaluations in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. In EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} has to identify more overlapping ciphertexts as the datasets are larger. The running time of ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} increases linearly with the dataset size for both cases. ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 5Ã—5\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

VI-B4 Effect of Duplication Percentage

FigureÂ 8 shows the effect of duplication percentage on EP-MPD running time, the average running time of clients, and ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} running time. FigureÂ 8(a) highlights the running time of EP-MPD as the duplication percentage changes. We note that in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, OPRF evaluations incur the most overwhelming running time, dominating all other running time costs. Overall, the running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant while that of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} linearly decreases as the duplication rate grows. In EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, the number of OPRF evaluations is independent of the duplication percentage, because the OPRF is always performed only when the clients are at the leaf level. However, in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, the number of PRP invocations decreases as clients move up the tree from the leaf level because a higher duplication percentage removes more elements in each level of the tree. The total running time of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 7Ã—7\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

Furthermore, the client-side running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant while that of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} linearly decreases as the duplication percentage increases, as shown in FigureÂ 8(b). The reason is identical to the observation of the EP-MPD running time. The number of PRP evaluations reduces while the number of OPRF evaluations does not. Similar to the prior experiment settings, the client time of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is higher than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} and is up to 7Ã—7\times slower. FigureÂ 8(c) shows the effect of duplication percentage on the running time of ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}. The ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant while in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} linearly decreases. The ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 2Ã—2\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

The overall running time of the symmetric key-based EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is considerably less than the public key-based EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. Nevertheless, the clients in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} need to perform more computations compared to those in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

VI-C FL with EP-MPD

VI-C1 Experimental Setup

We create an FL setting with varying levels of duplication to analyze the effect of EP-MPD on the model performance and training efficiency of CLM fine-tuning. We use GPT-2 Medium and GPT-2 Large CLMs from the GPT-2 [43] family of decoder-only models based on the Transformer [50] architecture. The GPT-2 Medium has 345 million parameters with 24 decoder blocks, 16 attention heads, and 1024 hidden sizes while GPT-2 Large has 774 million parameters with 36 decoder blocks, 20 attention heads, and 1280 hidden sizes. Both models have a sequence length of 1024 tokens.

We create 10 clients and experiment with the following 7 datasets. The Rotten Tomatoes and IMDB datasets contain movie reviews. The Sonnets and Plays datasets are a collection of works by William Shakespeare. Poetry is a collection of short poems by a variety of poets. Haiku and Short Jokes are a collection of short Japanese-style poems and Jokes from Reddit respectively. The language modeling task for each dataset is to learn how to generate text from the dataset's distribution. For all datasets, we create a Train and Test split in an 80:20 ratio. Model perplexity is evaluated on the Test set after training. We follow a two-step procedure to create the client datasets with x%percentğ‘¥x\% duplication. Initially, we equally distributed the Train set among all 10 clients. Next, we sample with replacement x%percentğ‘¥x\% of the original Train set. This subset is then again equally distributed among all clients. We perform 5 rounds of FL training with at most 10 epochs of local training. The GPT-2 Large models were trained for fewer epochs and with less data because they were overfitting to the Train set for more epochs and data. Additional details about the datasets and FL training hyperparameters can be found in AppendixÂ -E.

VI-C2 FL model performance

We measure the perplexity of the final model on the Test set to assess the impact of various duplication levels on model performance. TableÂ I shows the results of perplexity (PP) and improvement rate (IR). IR refers to the percentage of improvement in perplexity after deduplication. For example, the Haiku dataset with GPT-2 Medium and 30% duplication shows an IR of 5.36% from 3.73 to 3.53 after deduplication. The deduplicated client datasets represent the baseline perplexity.

The blue text in the table highlights the largest improvement in perplexity, which is for the Plays dataset with GPT-2 Medium. We observe an improvement rate of 19.61%percent19.6119.61\% from 34.88 to 28.04 for 30%percent3030\% duplication. The Plays dataset in general has a higher perplexity than other datasets as it is a relatively challenging task with longer sequences and fewer training samples. The impact of duplicates in such scenarios is aggravated. We observe a similar trend with the Sonnets dataset with a 13.64%percent13.6413.64\% improvement rate, which is also a difficult task with few samples and relatively long sequences.

The purple text highlights the least improvement in perplexity for the Rotten Tomatoes dataset with GPT-2 Medium. The 10%percent1010\% duplication results in a 1.7%percent1.71.7\% improvement rate from 3.63.63.6 to 3.533.533.53. Similarly, the Haiku and Short Jokes datasets exhibit smaller improvement rates across different levels of duplication, while maintaining low perplexity. We observe these trends because these datasets are relatively easier to learn with a greater number of training samples. The impact of duplicates in such cases is not as pronounced.

The red text highlights two scenarios where deduplication results in insignificant changes (<1%)<1\%) to perplexity. The Plays dataset with GPT-2 Medium shows an improvement of 0.28%percent0.280.28\% after deduplication with 10%percent1010\% duplication while the Sonnets dataset with GPT-2 Large worsens by 0.24%percent0.240.24\% after deduplication with 10%percent1010\% duplication. The reason for the ``noisy'' results for the Plays and Sonnets dataset is that both datasets have very few training data samples. A 10%percent1010\% duplication percentage merely adds 3âˆ’5353-5 duplicated data points to each client. Both datasets, however, show significant improvements for 20%percent2020\% and 30%percent3030\% duplication.

VI-C3 FL model training efficiency

We analyze the model training efficiency by computing the total GPU running time of all clients during training. The CPU-bound EP-MPD costs are negligible for 10 clients and at most 5,000 elements (the size of the largest dataset is 50,000 elements distributed among all clients). TableÂ II highlights the results for GPU running time. The Time column is the total GPU running time and IR is the percentage improvement compared to the running time within the deduplicated setting.

The blue text shows the largest improvement in running time of 27.95%percent27.9527.95\% from 33.13 minutes to 23.87 minutes in the GPT-2 Medium experiment with the Sonnets dataset. The purple text highlights the smallest improvement in running time of 7.33%percent7.337.33\% from 11.87 to 11.0 minutes in the Sonnets experiment with GPT-2 Large.

We observe a relatively consistent improvement trend of approximately 22%percent2222\%, 16%percent1616\%, and 8%percent88\% for 30%percent3030\%, 20%percent2020\%, and 10%percent1010\% duplication levels respectively. The GPT-2 Medium experiments show higher running times as these models were trained longer. We observe that the running time efficiency consistently improves across all duplication levels and experiments.

TablesÂ I and II demonstrate the effectiveness of applying EP-MPD to FL of language models. The experiments show improvements of up to 18%percent1818\% in perplexity and 27%percent2727\% in GPU running time. Deduplication significantly reduces resource usage while enhancing the quality of FL models. The RTX A6000 GPU used in our experiments consumes 0.3 kWh of energy. As FL scales to larger datasets and more clients, the energy savings with EP-MPD become even more significant, contributing to more sustainable and cost-effective FL implementations, benefiting both the environment and the end-users.

VIII Related Works

A detailed deduplication method has been proposed in [31] that used existing techniques of finding duplicates such as suffix array [36] and MinHash [10]. However, there were no privacy requirements in this method as the data owner is responsible for local deduplication. As we consider the problem of deduplication in a distributive setting, thus our problem statement is fundamentally different from [31].

In [29], the problem of privacy-preserving deduplication by a centralized service was discussed â€“ there is a server that stores multiple users' files after removing duplicates. Their method involves a second server which helps in setting up keys for each user using an OPRF. Our work is different from [29] in many ways. First, we apply OPRF for encrypting the dataset elements, which allows efficient deduplication. Second, our deduplication requirement is more granular â€“ we want entries of users' datasets to be deduplicated. If the two datasets have the same elements irrespective of their order, then at the end of our deduplication, one of the users will receive an empty dataset and the other will receive their dataset unchanged. On the other hand, since [29] considers a file as a whole (not every set element), so two files M1subscriptğ‘€1M_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and M2subscriptğ‘€2M_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} have the same elements but in a different order will not be removed. Third, our public key-based deduplication protocol is federated as opposed to [29] which is centralized (all data is stored in a centralized server responsible for the deduplication). Fourth, [29] is a two-server setting â€“ one server helps in deduplication and the other stores the deduplicated files. In contrast, in our protocol apart from the users, we only have one third-party.

Another work along the lines of [29] is [33] which proposed Multi-Key Revealing Encryption (MKRE) that lets a server compress the encrypted files of multiple users by removing ciphertexts related to similar plaintexts. Their construction is based on message lock encryption, therefore, it is subject to dictionary attacks [34]. Our scheme is not vulnerable to such attacks and, as a result, provides a stronger security guarantee.

The work of [8] also has pointed out the need for data processing for ML and applied PSI-type tools. However, their problem statement is to find a mismatch in the datasets belonging to two participants, whereas we are considering finding duplicates (matching data) in sets belonging to two or more parties. Additionally, their application domain is narrow as they only considered labeled data. Their end goal is to find entries in two different sets where their features match but their corresponding labels do not match. On the other hand, our protocol supports both labeled and unlabeled data.

IX Conclusions

It was established in [31] that machine learning benefits significantly from deduplication. However, it was not evident how federated learning (FL) could benefit from deduplication without compromising data privacy. Our successful and efficient solution to this problem has paved the way for further applications. Our pioneering protocols, EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, can be employed in any distributed system to identify and efficiently remove duplicates. Although this paper considers elements as duplicates only if they are exact copies, there are scenarios where elements that are not exact matches but are sufficiently similar should also be treated as duplicates [31]. Our current primitives can easily be extended to address this case. By applying fuzzy hash functions, which map closely related elements to the same digest, the deduplication of near-match elements can be reduced to the problem of deduplication of exact-match elements, allowing the use of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} in distributed setups. While our system's application focuses on text-based learning, it can also be extended to other areas, such as image processing and speech recognition, thereby broadening its utility and impact.
