-A Security Proof of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}

In this section, we prove the security of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, i.e., Theorem 1.

Proof.

We consider a set of cases where in each case a party is corrupt.

-A1 Corrupt Client

In this case, for the sake of simplicity, we focus on the view of a client ğ’1,isubscriptğ’1ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} in ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Because the clients of both groups behave the same way, with the main difference being that a client in ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} generates a key and sends it to each client of ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Thus, the proof asserting the protocol is secure regarding a corrupt client in ğ’¢1subscriptğ’¢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} will imply the security of the same protocol concerning a client in ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}.

In the real execution of the protocol, the view of a client, ğ’1,isubscriptğ’1ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, is defined as follows:

{ğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—ğ’1,iğ’œ,EG-PSI(I)â€‹(S,âˆ…)}S={S1,i,r1,i,kâ†’,R1,i,vâ†’1,i},subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—subscriptğ’1ğ‘–ğ’œsuperscriptEG-PSIIğ‘†ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†1ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘–â†’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…1ğ‘–subscriptâ†’ğ‘£1ğ‘–\{\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}}(S,\emptyset)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}=\{S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i},r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i},\vec{k},R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i},\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}\},

where Sğ‘†S is the set containing all clients' sets, r1,isubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘–r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} is the outcome of internal random coins of ğ’1,isubscriptğ’1ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, kâ†’=[ki,1,â€¦,ki,m]â†’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘š\vec{k}=[k_{\scriptscriptstyle i,1},\ldots,k_{\scriptscriptstyle i,m}] is a vector of mğ‘šm keys received from the clients of ğ’¢0subscriptğ’¢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}, R1,isubscriptğ‘…1ğ‘–R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} is the encrypted intersection ğ’1,isubscriptğ’1ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} received from ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}, and vâ†’j,isubscriptâ†’ğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘–\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} equals [vâ†’j,i,1,â€¦,vâ†’j,i,m]subscriptâ†’ğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptâ†’ğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘š[\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i,1},\ldots,\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i,m}], each lğ‘™l-th vector in vâ†’j,isubscriptâ†’ğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘–\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} contains the elements that are common between ğ’1,isubscriptğ’1ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}'s set and the set that belongs to the lğ‘™l-th client in the other group.

We proceed to construct a simulator, ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ’1,isubscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†subscriptğ’1ğ‘–\mathsf{Sim}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}}, in the ideal model. The simulator, receiving the client's input S1,isubscriptğ‘†1ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} and output vâ†’1,isubscriptâ†’ğ‘£1ğ‘–\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, operates as follows.

  3. 3.

Now, we are prepared to discuss that the two views are computationally indistinguishable. The input set S1,isubscriptğ‘†1ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} has identical distribution in both models, as their elements are identical. Furthermore, since we are in the semi-honest model, in the real execution of the protocol, the client picks its random coins r1,isubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘–r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} according to the protocol description. In the ideal model, coins r1,iâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²1ğ‘–r^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} have been selected uniformly at random. Therefore r1,isubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘–r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} and r1,iâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²1ğ‘–r^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} have identical distributions. Vectors kâ†’â†’ğ‘˜\vec{k} and kâ†’â€²superscriptâ†’ğ‘˜â€²\vec{k}^{\prime} have identical distributions too because their elements have been chosen uniformly at random.

In the real model, R1,isubscriptğ‘…1ğ‘–R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} contains the encrypted elements of vâ†’1,isubscriptâ†’ğ‘£1ğ‘–\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, where the keys in kâ†’â†’ğ‘˜\vec{k} are used for the encryption by applying the ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ™¿ğšğ™¿\mathtt{PRP}. Thus, Rğ‘…R and Râ€²superscriptğ‘…â€²R^{\prime} have identical distributions. Furthermore, elements of vâ†’1,isubscriptâ†’ğ‘£1ğ‘–\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} are identical in both models; therefore, they have identical distributions in the real and ideal models.

We conclude that the views in the real and ideal models are indistinguishable.

We proceed to demonstrate that the views in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable. In the real model, each elements of a set Sj,iâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—ğ‘–S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} is an output of ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ™¿ğšğ™¿\mathtt{PRP}. However, in the ideal model, each element of a set Sj,iâ€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²ğ‘—ğ‘–S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} has been picked uniformly at random (from the range of ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ™¿ğšğ™¿\mathtt{PRP}). By the security of ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ™¿ğšğ™¿\mathtt{PRP} (i.e., an output of ğ™¿ğšğ™¿ğ™¿ğšğ™¿\mathtt{PRP} is computationally indistinguishable from a random value), sets' elements in the real and ideal model are computationally indistinguishable.

Moreover, the size of the intersection between each set S0,iâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²0ğ‘–S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} and each set S1,lâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1ğ‘™S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,l} (in the real model) equals the size of the intersection between each set S0,iâ€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²0ğ‘–S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} and each set S1,lâ€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²1ğ‘™S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,l} (in the ideal model). Furthermore, the size of each Sj,iâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—ğ‘–S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} in the real model equals the size of the corresponding set Sj,iâ€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²ğ‘—ğ‘–S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} in the ideal model. Hence, sets S0,1â€²,â€¦,S0,mâ€²,S1,1â€²,â€¦,S1,mâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²01â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²0ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²11â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1ğ‘š{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m} in the real model are computationally indistinguishable from sets S0,1â€²â€²,â€¦,S0,mâ€²â€²,S1,1â€²â€²,â€¦,S1,mâ€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²01â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²0ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²11â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²â€²1ğ‘š{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m} in the ideal model.

Thus, the views in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable. âˆ

-B Security Proof of EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}

Proof (sketch).

It is not hard to simulate parties' views. ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}'s view in the real model can be easily simulated given that the main information it learns within the protocol execution includes its view during the invocation of the OPRF instances (but not the outputs of OPRF). If OPRF is secure, then the views of ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE} within the real and ideal model will be computationally indistinguishable in this protocol.

Each client's view (in the real execution of the protocol) mainly includes the outputs of OPRF received from its counterparts and the exchanged messages during OPRF's execution with ğ’¯â€‹â„°â€‹â„°ğ’¯â„°â„°\mathcal{TEE}. Due to the security of OPRF, an output of OPRF is computationally indistinguishable from a value picked uniformly at random from the output range of OPRF. Also, the messages each client receives during the execution of OPRF can be simulated, due to the security of OPRF. âˆ

-C Security Proof of EP-MPD

In this section, we prove the security of EP-MPD, i.e., Theorem 3. For the sake of concreteness and because we have provided a detailed proof for EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, we will prove Theorem 3 when EP-MPD relies on EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. The proof for EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}-based EP-MPD will easily follow.

Proof.

Now, we are prepared to show that the two views (in the real and ideal models) are computationally indistinguishable. The input Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} in both models are identical, therefore they will have identical distribution.

Due to the security of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, for every level dğ‘‘d, ğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—ğ’i,dğ’œ,EG-PSI(I)superscriptsubscriptğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—subscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ’œsuperscriptEG-PSII\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},d}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}} in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable, as demonstrated in the proof of Theorem 1. Furthermore, the intersection vâ†’i,dsubscriptâ†’ğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘‘\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i,d} that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} learns at every level dğ‘‘d in the real and ideal model are identical, thus they are indistinguishable.

Hence, the views of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable. âˆ

-D Related Work in PSI Research

Since their introduction in [19], numerous PSIs have been designed. In general, PSIs fall into two broad categories traditional and delegated. In traditional PSIs, clients (i.e., data owners) compute the result interactively using their data stored locally. In this research line, researchers in [45] introduced two two-party PSIs, one secure against semi-honest and the other against malicious (or active) adversaries. These protocols are the fastest two-party PSIs to date. They use Oblivious Key-Value Stores (OKVS) data structure and Vector Oblivious Linear Evaluation (VOLE). These solutions' computation cost is Oâ€‹(c)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(c), where cğ‘c is a set's cardinality. They also impose Oâ€‹(câ€‹logâ¡c2+Îº)ğ‘‚ğ‘superscriptğ‘2ğœ…O(c\log c^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}+\kappa) and Oâ€‹(câ‹…Îº)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘ğœ…O(c\cdot\kappa) communication costs in the semi-honest and malicious models respectively, where Îºğœ…\kappa is a security parameter.

Dorre et al. [17] proposed an efficient two-party PSI that requires each party to locally posses a secure hardware, a requirement that may not always be possible to meet. The scheme further relies on a hash function and deterministic symmetric-key encryption. The scheme's communication complexity is Oâ€‹(pâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹yâ€‹(Îº)+|S|â€‹Î»)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¦ğœ…ğ‘†ğœ†O(poly(\kappa)+|S|\lambda) and its computation complexity is Oâ€‹((2â‹…|S|)â‹…pâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹yâ€‹(Îºâ‹…l))ğ‘‚â‹…â‹…2ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¦â‹…ğœ…ğ‘™O((2\cdot|S|)\cdot poly(\kappa\cdot l)), where lğ‘™l is a set element's bit size and Î»ğœ†\lambda is a security parameter. As the authors stated, the protocol cannot directly support multiple more than two parties.

Furthermore, researchers developed PSIs that allows multiple (i.e., more than two) parties to compute the intersection. The multi-party PSIs in [24, 30] are secure against semi-honest adversaries while those proposed in [6, 20, 53, 30, 40] were developed to remain secure against active ones. The protocols in [30] and [40] are the most efficient multi-party PSIs designed to be secure against passive and active adversaries respectively. The computation and communication complexities of the PSI in [30] are Oâ€‹(câ‹…m2+câ‹…m)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘superscriptğ‘š2â‹…ğ‘ğ‘šO(c\cdot m^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}+c\cdot m) and Oâ€‹(câ‹…m2)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘superscriptğ‘š2O(c\cdot m^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}). The PSI in [40] has a parameter tğ‘¡t that determines how many parties can collude with each other and must be set before the protocol's execution, where tâˆˆ[2,m)ğ‘¡2ğ‘št\in[2,m). Its computation and communication complexities are Oâ€‹(câ‹…Îºâ€‹(m+t2âˆ’tâ€‹(m+1)))ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘ğœ…ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘¡ğ‘š1O(c\cdot\kappa(m+t^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}-t(m+1))) and Oâ€‹(câ‹…mâ‹…Îº)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘ğ‘šğœ…O(c\cdot m\cdot\kappa) respectively.

Delegated PSIs use cloud computing for computation and/or storage. These PSIs can be further categorized into those that allow one-off and repeated delegation of PSI computation. The most efficient one that supports one-off delegation is [26], designed for the two-party setting, with an overhead of Oâ€‹(c)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(c). Researchers also proposed a multi-party PSI that supports repeated delegation and efficient updates [16]. It imposes Oâ€‹(hâ‹…d2â‹…m)ğ‘‚â‹…â„superscriptğ‘‘2ğ‘šO(h\cdot d^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}\cdot m) and Oâ€‹(hâ‹…dâ‹…m)ğ‘‚â‹…â„ğ‘‘ğ‘šO(h\cdot d\cdot m) computation and communication costs respectively, during the PSI computation. Furthermore, to incentivize clients to participate in a PSI protocol and share their sensitive inputs, researchers proposed a PSI that rewards participants [1].

Thus, despite the development of numerous two-party and multiple-party PSIs, none of them to date can match the features offered by our PSIs.

-E Datasets and FL Hyperparameters

We use the following datasets in our study:

  1. 1.

    Haiku222https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/bfbarry/haiku-dataset: This dataset contains 15,281 Haikus scraped from ``reddit.com/r/haiku''. Haiku is a Japanese style of short poetry.

  2. 2.

    Rotten Tomatoes333https://huggingface.co/datasets/cornell-movie-review-data/rotten_tomatoes: It contains 10,662 movie reviews from the Rotten Tomatoes movie critic website. Originally intended for sentiment analysis, the dataset has 5,331 positive and negative reviews each. In our experiments, we ignore the sentiment of the reviews and train the CLM only on the review.

  3. 3.

    Short Jokes444https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/abhinavmoudgil95/short-jokes: It contains 231,657 jokes scraped from Reddit. We randomly sample 50,000 jokes for our experiments.

  4. 4.

    Poetry555https://huggingface.co/datasets/merve/poetry: It contains 573 poems from the Renaissance and Modern eras by various poets.

  5. 5.

    IMDB [35]: This dataset contains 50,000 movie reviews from the IMDB movie critic website. Similar to the Rotten Tomatoes dataset, the IMDB dataset was originally intended for sentiment analysis. We ignore the sentiment of each review and only train the CLM on the review.

  6. 6.

    Sonnets666https://huggingface.co/datasets/Lambent/shakespeare_sonnets_diffused: This dataset contains 460 sonnets (including variations) from William Shakespeare. Sonnets are 14-line poems with variable rhyme schemes

  7. 7.

    Plays777https://huggingface.co/datasets/Trelis/tiny-shakespeare: It contains 521 plays from William Shakespeare.

We train the GPT-2 Medium and GPT-2 Large models for 5â€‹â€“â€‹105â€“105\text{--}10 and 1â€‹â€“â€‹21â€“21\text{--}2 local epochs respectively. Both models are trained for 5 rounds. The Haiku GPT-2 Large was trained for 1 epoch while the other GPT-2 Large models were trained for 2 epochs. The Poetry and Sonnets GPT-2 Medium models were trained for 10 epochs while the others were trained for 5 epochs. We observe that training GPT-2 Large for more epochs and data results in overfitting and poor Test set perplexity across all duplication levels.

For all experiments, we use a learning of 5Ã—10âˆ’55superscript1055\times 10^{\scriptscriptstyle-5} with the AdamW [32] optimizer. We use a linear warm-up schedule with 10% of the training steps as warm-up steps. We use â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}-norm clipping for the gradients and set the threshold to 1.0. We set the sequence length for the datasets as follows:

  1. 1.

    Haiku: 100

  2. 2.

    Rotten Tomatoes: 200

  3. 3.

    Short Jokes: 100

  4. 4.

    Poetry: 1000

  5. 5.

    IMDB: 500

  6. 6.

    Sonnets: 400

  7. 7.

    Plays: 1000

For the Short Jokes dataset, we randomly sample 50,000 elements to ensure the running time is feasible as we train with 10 clients. We set the batch size to values in the range [4,32]432[4,32], depending on the sequence length and model size to ensure that training can be performed on one RTX A6000 GPU. We use a Train/Test split of 80/20 for all datasets. In the case of datasets like IMDB that have a separate Test set, we combine the original Train and Test sets into a single dataset, shuffle it, and then create 80:20 splits. We fix the random seed to 123 for the Numpy, PyTorch, and Python random number generators to ensure the reproducibility of our results.
